Call me Aqua
I’m a freelance dog-petter, a somewhat committed blogger and an advocator for naps and world peace.
May 20, 2016

Being Naive: Puppies and Other Things

When I was a little girl, I so desperately wanted to reach these red, shiny berries on the tree in my neighbour’s front yard. If only I was a little bit taller or the tree a little bit shorter. Fortunately, there was a wooden picnic table just underneath the tree. Unfortunately, despite balancing on my tippy toes I was still unable to reach the berries. Even more intolerable were the few millimetres between my finger tips and the berries.

If developmental psychology has taught me anything it is that children move through stages sequentially. And that, is exactly what I did. My four-year-old self was especially fond of problem-solving and trial-and-error, and trial-and-error is exactly what transpired. Clearly, the next logical step was to jump for the berries. I proceeded to launch myself off the picnic table in hopes of plucking those beautiful, red berries from the tree.

I missed the berries (which were also poisonous).

The ground broke my fall.

My bottom teeth did an exceptional job at lacerating my chin open.

The scar on my face reminds me of this event every day.

When I was a little girl, I went through a “gangster” phase which I attribute to my love of Avril Lavigne. This was way before she entered her pink and black punk phase. This was when she truly was a sk8er boi complete with army pants, white tank and studded bracelets.

My mom asked me to run to the farmer’s market which was just on the other side of our backyard. Naturally, this seemed like the perfect opportunity to try out my new persona for the first time. I grabbed my largest pair of jeans and a “happy camper” t-shirt because it was army green. And I wore a faux jean baseball cap just slightly askew. When the man selling corn asked me how much I would like, this is what happened:

A small blonde child of 6 years old wearing the strangest outfit said, “2 cob,” in a deep voice, because that’s how gangsters spoke.

She also grabbed the white plastic bag filled with corn and swung it around her arm because she was imitating Drake from the Amanda show when he pretended to be “gangster.”

Upon leaving, she also called out, “Thanks dawg,” to the man.

When I think back to all my childhood experiences including, but not limited to, embarrassing, naive and ridiculous moments, I can’t help but think of a puppy. Puppies are so eager, inexperienced, spirited and easily influenced. That’s exactly what I was.

This year around January I started watching Teen Wolf though I had to stop watching it because it gave me far too many nightmares. About a week ago I fainted in the dentist’s office and this morning I walked out of the hospital after a night shift with a sippy cup in hand.

I was, and still am, a puppy.

There’s an unquestioning optimism that comes as standard equipment when you’re young, as I demonstrated with my graceful berry-picking act. I happen to consider this a gift from God. Time and routine are dream-squashers, “squashers” being interchangeable with “tramplers,” “exterminators,” and “demolishers.”

I once told someone that I planned to graduate, learn multiple languages and travel the world. They swiftly said, “Yeah, well you’ll probably reconsider that in a few years.” When I asked them why, they said, “Getting older sobers you up to the realities of life.”

It was from that day that I took a page out of Peter Pan’s book and vowed to NEVER, EVER grow up. EVER. At least, not like that.

God gives people the experiences he wants them to have in order to prepare them for the plan he’s designed for them. In fact, I can look back at my life thus far and see how God is and continues to form a vision for my life, which includes some sanctified naivety. Childlike faith is childlike for a reason.

“Critics who treat ‘adult’ as a term of approval, instead of as a merely descriptive term cannot be adult themselves … When I became a man I put away childish things, including the fear of childishness and the desire to be very grown-up.” — C.S. Lewis

Adulthood is dangerous because it can create the false expectation that at some magic point, we all grow up and figure things out. In reality, we’re adrift in a sea of people who are literally making it up as we go. I say that adulthood is dangerous because we may be influenced into believing that the decisions we make are without the consequences we could expect when we’re younger. Using “adult” as a term of approval promotes the idea that adulthood carries a sense of seriousness and expertise lacked by childhood.

Scripture makes it clear that this is not the case.

Let the children come to me. Don’t stop them! For the Kingdom of Heaven belongs to those who are like these children. (Matthew 19:14)

When you look at the lives of people who are called to do great things for God, you’ll notice three things:

  1. They offer excuses.
  2. God is not surprised.
  3. God doesn’t change his mind.

This is what happens when you “get older.” The mind floods with reasons why it will never work and you’ll remember all the times you’ve failed or embarrassed yourself before (by dressing up like a gangster..which I thought was quite fetching).

But sanctified naivety and courageous, unwavering faith in God never cowers in the darkness. The darker it gets, the brighter the light shines.

We are the light of the world: we cannot be hidden — and we have no reason to hide (Matthew 5:14).

Excuse my melodramatic tendencies while I compare this past year to being thrown to the wolves. Often times, I was (am) unsure of myself, unprepared and utterly afraid. I had to sit down with my head between my knees while watching someone start an IV for goodness’ sake.

I am, and will continue to be, a puppy. Naive, eager to please to the point of exhaustion, and incredibly inexperienced in this thing we call “life.” The good thing though is that I have a master who prepares me for the world and trains me faithfully; I need only listen.

I am a child of God and I don’t want to grow up into an “adult,” who thinks that big dreams are naive and that growing up means knowing every thing. Amazing dreams are necessary for achieving amazing things.

I guess my point here is that if you are a puppy and you feel like you are so young, so inexperienced and so incredibly afraid of what awaits you in this life, you are not alone. Embrace that naivety and never stop believing that you can achieve HUGE THINGS, AMAZING THINGS, HARD THINGS.

Be a puppy, brave the wolves and dream big fur-ever.
